entry.title: Re: T169G is not reporting the same values entered in OMR...
entry.content:
Why the mismatch occurs is because of the following:

  • OMR6: You maintain tolerance limits for invoice verification in a given currency.
  • TCURX: This table defines decimal places for currencies. For IDR (Indonesian Rupiah), SAP standard sets 0 decimals.
  • T169G: Stores the tolerance values. However, internally SAP always keeps amounts in two decimal places (like ‚Äúcurrency with cents‚Äù), even if TCURX says 0 decimals.

So when you enter ‚Äú4,000,000 IDR‚Äù in OMR6, the system converts it into the internal representation with 2 decimals. In T169G, you‚Äôll see ‚Äú40,000.00‚Äù (effectively scaled down by 100). That‚Äôs why you see the value expressed in thousands with decimals ‚Äî it‚Äôs not wrong, it‚Äôs how SAP stores it internally.

So to overcome from this, you just have to enter values in OMR6 considering the scaling. For example, if you want a tolerance of 4,000,000 IDR, you must enter 40000 in OMR6 (because internally SAP multiplies by 100).

entry.title: Re: Harmonizing UI5 URLs: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN
entry.content:
This change broke all of our UI5 applications across all customer landscapes at once. Because we rely on SAP-provided CDN resources, our customers experienced outages that were completely outside of their control and ours.

The biggest issue is loss of customer trust. When applications stop working due to an unannounced or insufficiently communicated infrastructure change from SAP, customers don‚Äôt see this as a ‚ÄúCDN update‚Äù they see it as our application being unreliable. This damages confidence in partners and implementers who are building on SAP‚Äôs officially recommended resources.

Changes of this nature must be treated as breaking changes, with prominent communication, long transition periods, and clear migration guidance. Otherwise, the operational and reputational cost is unfairly pushed onto customers and partners.

entry.title: Re: Calculating surcharges on contract manufacturing
entry.content:
Why surcharges are not determined with Sobsl 30 because, Special procurement key 30 tells the system: ‚ÄúThis material is procured externally via subcontracting.‚Äù In costing, the system then switches to the subcontracting calculation schema:

  • It pulls the subcontracting charge from the info record.
  • It adds the components consumed in subcontracting.

However, when Sobsl 30 is active, the system does not apply standard surcharges/overheads from the costing sheet, because subcontracting is treated as a special case. That‚Äôs why you see surcharges when Sobsl is removed (normal external procurement), but not when subcontracting is active.

In Public Cloud, surcharge determination is tied to the procurement type. For subcontracting (Sobsl 30), surcharges are not automatically applied. This is by design: SAP assumes the subcontracting charge already reflects the agreed cost, and additional surcharges are not layered on top.

Options to achieve your requirement

Adjust costing sheet logic
Create a costing sheet variant that explicitly includes subcontracting procurement in the surcharge base. This requires configuration in Manage Costing Sheets app (Public Cloud equivalent of SPRO).

Use condition records in purchasing
Maintain surcharges directly in the info record conditions for subcontracting vendor. This way, the surcharge is part of the subcontracting price itself.

Custom logic (BAdI in Public Cloud)
If standard configuration doesn‚Äôt allow surcharges with Sobsl 30, you can implement a Custom Logic enhancement to add surcharges during costing runs.

entry.title: Re: Reversal of Production
entry.content:
Posting date logic: MF41 uses the current system date (or the posting date entered in the reversal run) for FI/MM postings. If you executed the reversal in January 2026 without manually setting the posting date back to December 2025, the system posts in 2026.

Period control: SAP checks the open posting periods in FI/MM. If period 12/2025 was already closed, the system cannot post back into 2025 and defaults to the next open period (January 2026).

Stock visibility: Because the reversal was posted in 2026, the system still shows stock as of 31.12.2025. From a reporting perspective, this looks like inventory wasn‚Äôt cleared at year‚Äëend.

To fix this, check the below areas

Check posting periods
In FI/MM, confirm whether December 2025 is open for postings. If it was closed, the reversal could only go into January 2026.

Re‚Äërun MF41 with correct posting date
Enter 31.12.2025 (or another December date) explicitly as the posting date. Ensure FI/MM period 12/2025 is open.

If period is closed
You cannot repost into 2025 unless you reopen the period (which is usually avoided after year‚Äëend close). In that case, the stock will remain visible as of 31.12.2025, and the correction will only appear in 2026.

Reporting adjustment
If reopening is not allowed, you may need to explain in audit/closing notes that the reversal was executed in January, and adjust reporting manually (e.g., via reclassification or disclosure).

I created my own IC pricing procedure and I detetrmine it by standard customizing.

There is no standard way to copy the price from the PO to the IC credit memo, so you need to determine the prices with condition technique. But there is way to enhance this a bit.

In my case, I use condition type PI01 in the sales pricing procedure. In the PO, I use PIC1 (in MM module).

PIC1 (MM) condition type refers to PI01 (SD). So I need to create only condition records for PI01.

Both have the sames access sequence assigned.

entry.title: Re: Harmonizing UI5 URLs: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN
entry.content:
@pmuessig for us, I think the problem is related to the Content-Security policy. As the CDN is a different domain to the domain where the app is loaded from, we will explicitly allow that URL. However, because of the redirect, it ends up being a completely different URL, so where openui5.hana.ondemand.com will be acceptable from a security point of view, sdk.openui5.org will not. There are a couple of fixes. One was to add another exception to the security, but the better fix is to change the url in our server to the new url which automatically will then have the security exception applied. I don't know the exact details, as I concentrate on the UI rather than the node layer of our app, but we are using helmet and it seems related to how the security exceptions are added.

As far as making the announcment is concerned I, and I would think most developers have https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/ permenantly open and this is my go to page which I go to many times a day. Maybe a banner on that page warning of the impact of new changes would be a place to annouce things like this. Fortunately, we have the location of the resources as an envirnment variable which our customers can change to get going again, but were this not the case, then we would need more time to get patches prepared and send to our customers.

@pmuessig  We are facing the exact issue described by @andyfletcher990 , and the impact on our side is severe.

This change has broken multiple production applications across a large number of customer systems simultaneously. Due to the scale at which we operate, it is not realistically possible to roll out fixes to all customers immediately. Many customers are understandably reluctant to import transports directly into production, and each customer runs a different version of our applications based on their individual setups and system landscapes.

As a result, this change has significantly increased testing and coordination effort for every single customer. We cannot simply push the latest changes everywhere, nor do we have a straightforward remediation path for applications that are already failing in production today.

Given the scale and impact, is it possible to revert this change or delay the redirection for at least a few more days? Even a short grace period would give partners time to prepare, test, and coordinate proper fixes, instead of dealing with ongoing production outages.

entry.title: Asynchronous Logging in SAP API Management
entry.content:
Introduction

When configuring APIs in SAP API Management, it is as important aspect to configure info logging or error logging and then send it across to the downstream systems like Loggly, ServiceNow etc. which is Synchronous mode by default. Since the default logging in API Proxies takes place in Synchronous mode, the consumer of the API Proxy must wait for all backend calls to finish, which increases the total response time which is a big concern in the Request-Reply pattern.

This blog explains how to implement true asynchronous logging in SAP API Management. The main objective of this blog is to showcase the approach of implementing Asynchronous logging in APIM and improve the response time which is so critical for Request-Reply Pattern.

Synchronous vs Asynchronous Logging

Before building the necessary Artifacts for enabling Asynchronous logging, let‚Äôs understand the behavioral difference:

Synchronous Logging

When a request arrives, the API proxy processes it to the target backend and then directly calls logging systems like Loggly where in the result could be success or failure. If it is success ,the flow moves into the PostFlow of the proxy endpoint. Here, the proxy makes a synchronous call to the logging system. The response is sent to the consumer only after this logging call finishes, which increases the overall response time. If there is a failure, the flow triggers FaultRules where error logging happens synchronously, and the error response is sent only after the logging call completes.

Asynchronous Logging

When a request arrives, the API proxy processes it and immediately sends the response back to the api proxy consumer due to async mode of logging. Logging operations happen separately in the background by queuing messages to JMS for later processing. Background processes handle the actual delivery to Loggly or other logging platforms. If logging fails, it gets retried without impacting the response time.

Compared to synchronous logging, this approach helps APIs respond faster, keeps logging problems away and perform well even during high traffic.

Architecture Overview

Implementation Steps:

Step 1:Create a proxy endpoint:

After creating the proxy endpoint, include the following policies:

Step 2: Extract the Control Header

First, we add a header to control when asynchronous logging should be used.

Policy: ExtractVariables-Flag.xml

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<ExtractVariables async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
<! -- Extract AsyncFlag from incoming HTTP header -->
    <Header name="AsyncFlag">
        <Pattern>{AsyncFlag}</Pattern>
    </Header>
<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
    <Source>request</Source>
</ExtractVariables>

This extracts the AsyncFlag header from the request. When the value is "true", asynchronous logging will be triggered.

Step 3: Prepare the Log Payload

Build the log message containing all the request details you want to capture. This structured JSON format makes it easy to search and analyze logs in Loggly.
Policy: AssignMessage-LogPayload.xml

<!-- This policy assigns a log payload JSON to a variable -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
  <AssignVariable>
    <Name>LogPayload</Name>
    <Value>
      {
        "timestamp":‚Äùsystem.timestamp}",
        "messageId":"{messageid}",
        "apiProxy":"{apiproxy.name}",
        "environment":"{environment.name}",
        "logLevel":"INFO",
        "description":"Request received for processing",
        "syncFlag":"{req.AsyncFlag}",
        "targetURL":"{target.url}"
      }
    </Value>
  </AssignVariable>
<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
  <AssignTo createNew="false" type="request">request</AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

This creates a variable called LogPayload containing a JSON object.

Step 4: Configure the Async Log Request

Prepare the request object that will be used to send logs asynchronously. This step structures how the log data will be transmitted to the logging system.

Policy: AssignMessage-AsyncLogRequest.xml

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
<!-- Assign payload and headers for async log request -->
  <AssignVariable>
    <Name>AsyncLogRequest.payload</Name>
    <Value>{logPayload}</Value>
  </AssignVariable>
<AssignVariable>
    <Name>AsyncLogRequest.header.Content-Type</Name>
    <Value>application/json</Value>
  </AssignVariable>
<AssignVariable>
    <Name>AsyncLogRequest.verb</Name>
    <Value>POST</Value>
  </AssignVariable>
<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
  <AssignTo createNew="true" type="request">AsyncLogRequest</AssignTo>

Step 5: Configure Authentication Credentials

Configure the authentication needed to securely call your SAP Cloud Integration endpoint. Store your cloud integration client credentials and encode them into the proper authorization header format that will be used when sending logs.

Step 6: Trigger Asynchronous Logging via Integration Flow and JMS

In this step, the API proxy hands over the prepared log payload to an integration endpoint asynchronously, and from there the message is written into a JMS queue. This asynchronous approach ensures that it does not wait for the logging response and no delay to the consumer.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<ServiceCallout async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Request clearPayload="true">
        <Set>
            <Headers>
                <Header name="Content-Type">application/json</Header>
                <Header name="Authorization">{sapapim.Authorization}</Header>
            </Headers>
            <Payload contentType="application/json">{logPayload}</Payload>
            <Verb>POST</Verb>
        </Set>
        <IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
    </Request>
    <Response>cpi.logresponse</Response>

    <Timeout>30000</Timeout>

    <HTTPTargetConnection>
        <URL>https://{cpi-tenant-url}/http/Async_toJMS</URL>
    </HTTPTargetConnection>
</ServiceCallout>

Important: This policy is configured to be executed only when the condition request.header.AsyncFlag = "true" is met. This means asynchronous logging is triggered based on the header value sent in the request.

Once the integration endpoint receives the log payload, it stores the message in a JMS queue instead of sending it directly to Loggly or another logging system. This is where real asynchronous behavior comes from.

Why JMS helps with asynchronous logging?

JMS queues let the integration flow accept a log message, drop it into a queue, and return immediately. The queue takes responsibility for the message from that point on. A separate consumer reads from the queue later and sends the log to Loggly or any other target system such as service now etc.

This means the logging process is completely decoupled from the original request. The API response is not tied to how fast Loggly responds or whether it is even available at that moment. The request finishes as soon as the business logic is done, while JMS guarantees that the log will be processed in the background, which is exactly the asynchronous behavior we want.

Conclusion

Asynchronous logging keeps logging out of the API‚Äôs critical execution path. The API finishes its business processing and sends the response back to the client right away, while logs are passed in the background to the integration layer and JMS for delivery to Loggly.

This way, response times stay fast, logging delays or outages don‚Äôt affect the API, and you still get all the visibility needed for monitoring and troubleshooting. It‚Äôs a practical approach that balances performance, reliability, and observability, making it a good fit for high-volume, enterprise APIs.

entry.title: 'Wait up to seconds' command not respected
entry.content:
Hello community, I am doing mass printing via SUBMIT on 'rsnast00', and inside the loop I placed a command 'wait up to 10 seconds' to have a 10‚Äësecond interval between each print:

    LOOP AT tg_ztbmpmc025 ASSIGNING <fg_ztbmpmc025>.

      CLEAR vg_valid_flag.

      CALL FUNCTION 'GET_PRINT_PARAMETERS'
        EXPORTING
          immediately            = abap_true
          destination            = 'LOCL'
          mode                   = 'BATCH'
          no_dialog              = abap_true
        IMPORTING
          out_parameters         = wg_print_parameters
          valid                  = vg_valid_flag
        EXCEPTIONS
          archive_info_not_found = 1
          invalid_print_params   = 2
          invalid_archive_params = 3
          OTHERS                 = 4.

      IF vg_valid_flag = abap_true.

        AUTHORITY-CHECK OBJECT 'F_NFBA'
             ID 'ACTVT' FIELD '35'.
        " raise error and exit if failure
        SUBMIT rsnast00
          WITH s_kappl = 'NF' " Nota Fiscal
          WITH s_objky = <fg_ztbmpmc025>-docnum
          TO SAP-SPOOL
          SPOOL PARAMETERS   wg_print_parameters
          ARCHIVE PARAMETERS wg_archive_parameters
          WITHOUT SPOOL DYNPRO
          AND RETURN.
        IF sy-subrc = 0.
          <fg_ztbmpmc025>-concluido = abap_true.
          COMMIT WORK AND WAIT.
        ENDIF.

        WAIT UP TO 10 SECONDS.

      ENDIF.

    ENDLOOP.

But this 10‚Äësecond interval is not being respected, and it is printing one after another, running in the background.

 

My question is: Is the 'Wait up to seconds' command not respected when a program runs in the background? Is there another way I can insert a delay between the prints?

entry.title: Time tracking - Pairing using only one time type event (like Clock in P01)
entry.content:
Dear experts,

Is it possible in Time tracking SuccessFactors to pair events based only on one event like Clock in event (P01). 

Some terminal sends only one event time type like P01 for clock in. For example employee punches like following : 

Employee arrives at: 9h30am ( Clock in P01) 

Employee take a break : 12h00 am ( Clock in P01) 

Employee  return to work again: 13h00 ( Clock in P01)

Employee  finishes his work : 17h00( Clock in P01)

This is false.

SuccessFactors generates the following time working type records:

Time type WORK: 9h30 - 12h00

Time type WORK: 12h00 - 13h00

Time type WORK: 13h00 - 17h00

 

Our customer need:

Time type WORK: 9h30 - 12h00

Time type WORK: 13h00 - 17h00

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Harmonizing UI5 URLs: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN
entry.content:
@pmuessig Thanks a lot for the quick response, openness, and for rolling back the change. We really appreciate how promptly this was handled and our applications are working fine again now.

We will immediately plan the move to the new CDN URLs and ensure a smooth and successful transition for our customers. Thanks again for the quick engagement and support.

entry.title: Re: Spool List for Batch Job V_V2
entry.content:
When you run V_V2 interactively, you can toggle between the default log view (technical, cycle‚Äëbased messages) and the list view (clearer, order‚Äëoriented results). When you run V_V2 in batch/job mode, the system always writes the default log view to the spool. The ‚Äúlist view‚Äù is a frontend presentation, not a separate spool output. That‚Äôs why your emailed spool only contains the confusing log.

Why you can‚Äôt change it directly is because, the clearer list view is generated by the ALV display layer in the dialog transaction. Batch jobs don‚Äôt trigger that ALV rendering ‚Äî they only output the technical log. There‚Äôs no standard SAP switch to make the spool adopt the list view instead.

Some options are

Use the report behind V_V2
V_V2 calls program SDV03V02 (Rescheduling). You can run this program directly with variants and choose output options. Some clients create a custom variant or copy the program to adjust the output format.

Download the list view interactively
Run V_V2 manually, switch to the list view, and export to Excel/CSV. This gives you the clearer format for distribution, though not automated.

Custom development / enhancement
ABAP enhancement or wrapper report can be built to generate the list view in batch and send it via email. This is the only way to automate the ‚Äúclear list‚Äù output.

entry.title: Creating Material Master Data in SAP S/4HANA Using RAP and EML .
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA, Article (Material) Master Data is one of the most critical master data objects, serving as the foundation for logistics, sales, inventory management, and financial processes. Every procurement transaction, sales order, stock movement, or valuation posting ultimately depends on the correctness and consistency of material master data.

Traditionally, material master records are created using standard transactions such as MM01 or by leveraging classic approaches like BAPIs and IDocs. While these methods are reliable, they are not always well-suited for modern application development, especially when building custom, extensible, and clean-core‚Äìcompliant solutions.

With the introduction of the RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP), SAP provides a standardized and future-ready way to build transactional applications using CDS views, behavior definitions, and Entity Manipulation Language (EML). RAP allows developers to model business objects declaratively while handling transactional consistency, validations, and authorizations in a structured manner.

In this article, we focus on creating Article (Material) Master Data using RAP and EML, by building an unmanaged RAP Business Object on top of standard SAP interface views such as I_Product, I_ProductDescription, and I_ProductPlant. Instead of directly calling classic BAPIs like BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA, the solution leverages EML operations on I_ProductTP to create and extend product data in a clean and controlled way.

The implementation demonstrates:

  • How to model a root CDS view entity for product creation
  • How to enrich it with UI annotations and value helps
  • How to define behavior logic for create, update, and custom actions
  • How to use EML to create product header data, descriptions, and plant extensions
  • How to handle validations, updates, and controlled operations within RAP behavior handlers

This approach enables the creation of a modern, API-driven, and extensible material master solution, which can easily be consumed by custom UIs, Fiori Elements, or external integrations‚Äîwhile remaining aligned with SAP‚Äôs clean-core strategy.

At the end of our development our RAP UI app will look like :

Step 1: Create a root CDS view entity

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Product demo with EML'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
@Search.searchable: true
define root view entity ZI_product_demo as select from I_Product as product
association [0..1] to I_ProductDescription as _descrp
on product.Product = _descrp.Product
association [0..*] to I_ProductPlant as _plante
                   on product.Product = _plante.Product
{
    key Product,
    IndustrySector,
    ProductType,
    BaseUnit,
    ProductGroup,
    PackagingMaterialGroup,
    
    _plante.Plant,
    
    _descrp.Language,
    _descrp.ProductDescription // Make association public
}

Step 2: Create a metadata extension for UI

@Metadata.layer: #CUSTOMER
@UI: {
    headerInfo: {
        typeName: 'Manage Products',
        typeNamePlural: 'Products',
        title: { type: #STANDARD, value: 'Product' },
        description: { value: 'ProductDescription' }
    }
}
annotate entity ZI_product_demo with
{
  .facet: [
    { id: 'ProductData', purpose: #STANDARD, type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE, label: 'Product Details', position: 10 }
  ]

  : { lineItem: [ { position: 10 },
                     { type: #FOR_ACTION, dataAction: 'extendplant', label: 'Extend Plant' } ],
        identification: [ { position: 10, label: 'Product' } ],
        selectionField: [ { position: 10 } ]  }
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{  entity: {   name: 'ZC_MAT_PRODUCT_VH' ,
                                                    element: 'Product' } } ]
  Product;
  : { lineItem: [ { position: 20 } ],
       identification: [ { position: 20, label: 'Industry Sector' } ],
       selectionField: [ { position: 20 } ] }
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{  entity: {   name: 'ZC_MAT_IndustrySector_VH' ,
                                                          element: 'IndustrySector' } } ]
  IndustrySector;

  : { lineItem: [ { position: 30 } ],
         identification: [ { position: 30, label: 'Product Type' } ],
         selectionField: [ { position: 30 } ] }
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{  entity: {   name: 'ZC_MAT_ProductType_VH' ,
                                                          element: 'ProductType' } } ]
  ProductType;

  : { lineItem: [ { position: 40 } ],
         identification: [ { position: 40, label: 'Base Unit' } ],
         selectionField: [ { position: 40 } ] }
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{  entity: {   name: 'ZC_MAT_BaseUnit_VH' ,
                                                          element: 'BaseUnit' } } ]
  BaseUnit;

  : { lineItem: [ { position: 50 } ],
         identification: [ { position: 50, label: 'Product Group' } ],
         selectionField: [ { position: 50 } ] }
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{  entity: {   name: 'ZC_MAT_ProductGroup_VH' ,
                                                         element: 'ProductGroup' } } ]

  ProductGroup;

  : { lineItem: [ { position: 60 } ],
         identification: [ { position: 60, label: 'Product Description' } ],
         selectionField: [ { position: 60 } ] }
  ProductDescription;

  : { lineItem: [ { position: 70 } ],
       identification: [ { position: 70, label: 'Packaging Material Group' } ],
       selectionField: [ { position: 70 } ] }
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{  entity: {   name: 'ZC_MAT_PackMaterialGroup_VH' ,
                                                        element: 'PackagingMaterialGroup' } } ]
  PackagingMaterialGroup;

  : { lineItem: [ { position: 80 } ],
       identification: [ { position: 80, label: 'Plant' } ],
       selectionField: [ { position: 80 } ] }
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{  entity: {   name: 'ZC_MAT_PLANT_VH' ,
                                                        element: 'Plant' } } ]

  Plant;

  : { lineItem: [ { position: 90 } ],
      identification: [ { position: 90, label: 'Language' } ],
      selectionField: [ { position: 90 } ] }
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{  entity: {   name: 'ZC_MAT_Language_VH' ,
                                                        element: 'Language' } } ]
  Language;
}

Since we are adding a extension to plant feature in our app we will need an abstract entity for plant.

Step 3: create abstract entity for plant

@EndUserText.label: 'abstract entity fo plant'
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true

define abstract entity ZI_PLANT_PARAM

{
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{  entity: {   name: 'ZC_MAT_PLANT_VH' ,
                                                        element: 'Plant' } } ]  
        plant : werks_d;
}

Step 4: Behavior definition will look like this, note that in action we have to specify the abstract entity name for plant extension feature :

unmanaged implementation in class zbp_i_product_demo unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZI_product_demo //alias <alias_name>
late numbering
lock master
authorization master ( global )
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;

  action extendplant parameter ZI_PLANT_PARAM result [1] $self;
  field ( readonly ) Plant;
  field ( readonly : update  ) Product,  ProductType, IndustrySector , PackagingMaterialGroup, Language;
  field ( mandatory : create ) BaseUnit , Language , ProductDescription, PackagingMaterialGroup,
                               IndustrySector, ProductType;
}

Step 5 : In the behavior implementation class we have to implement create , update, delete & extendplant method .

METHOD create.
    DATA lt_create_product TYPE TABLE FOR CREATE I_ProductTP_2.

*-- Read the data from app
    DATA(ls_entity) = entities[ 1 ].
    lv_product_type = ls_entity-ProductType.

    lt_create_product = VALUE #( (  %cid = 'product1'

                                  Product = ls_entity-Product
                                  ProductType = ls_entity-ProductType
                                  BaseUnit =  ls_entity-BaseUnit
                                  IndustrySector = ls_entity-IndustrySector
                                  PackagingProductGroup = ls_entity-PackagingMaterialGroup
                                  %control-Product = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
                                  %control-ProductType = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
                                  %control-BaseUnit = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
                                  %control-IndustrySector = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
                                  %control-PackagingProductGroup = if_abap_behv=>mk-on )  ).


*-- Call EML to replace BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA.
    MODIFY ENTITIES OF I_ProductTP_2 PRIVILEGED
           ENTITY Product
           CREATE FROM lt_create_product
           CREATE BY \_ProductDescription
           FIELDS ( Language ProductDescription  ) WITH VALUE #( (   %cid_ref = 'product1'
                                                                     Product = ls_entity-Product
                                                                     %target = VALUE #( (
                                                                     %cid = 'desc1'
                                                                     Product = ls_entity-Product
                                                                  Language = ls_entity-Language
                                                        ProductDescription = ls_entity-ProductDescription
                                                              )    ) ) )
                                                               MAPPED DATA(ls_mapped)
                                                               REPORTED DATA(ls_reported)
                                                               FAILED DATA(ls_failed)..
  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD update.
    DATA(ls_update_entity) = entities[ 1 ].

*-- Fetch existing data from database.
    SELECT SINGLE a~ProductType,
                  a~BaseUnit,
                  a~ProductGroup,
                  a~IndustrySector,
                  a~PackagingMaterialGroup,
                  b~ProductDescription,
                  b~Language
            FROM I_Product AS a
      INNER JOIN i_productdescription AS b
              ON a~Product = b~Product
           WHERE a~product EQ _update_entity-%key-Product
           INTO (ls_exist_product).

*-- Call EML to modify Product header data
    MODIFY ENTITIES OF I_ProductTP_2 PRIVILEGED
    ENTITY Product
    UPDATE FIELDS ( BaseUnit ProductGroup )
    WITH VALUE #( ( %key-Product = ls_update_entity-Product
                    BaseUnit = COND #( WHEN ls_update_entity-BaseUnit IS INITIAL THEN ls_exist_product-BaseUnit
                                       ELSE ls_update_entity-BaseUnit )

                    ProductGroup = COND #( WHEN ls_update_entity-ProductGroup IS INITIAL THEN ls_exist_product-ProductGroup
                                           ELSE ls_update_entity-ProductGroup )
                     ) )

*-- Call EML to modify product description
     ENTITY ProductDescription
     UPDATE FIELDS ( ProductDescription )
     WITH VALUE #( ( %key-Product = ls_update_entity-Product
                     %key-Language = ls_exist_product-Language
                     ProductDescription = COND #( WHEN ls_update_entity-ProductDescription IS INITIAL THEN ls_exist_product-ProductDescription
                                                  ELSE ls_update_entity-ProductDescription  ) ) )
    MAPPED DATA(ls_mapped)
    REPORTED DATA(ls_reported)
    FAILED DATA(ls_failed).
  ENMETHOD.


  METHOD delete.
*-- Turn off delete functionality
    APPEND VALUE #( %tky = keys[ 1 ]-%tky ) TO failed-zi_product_demo.
    APPEND VALUE #( %tky = keys[ 1 ]-%tky
                    %msg = new_message_with_text( severity = if_abap_behv_message=>severity-error
                                                  text = 'Delete functionality is not enabled' )
                   ) TO reported-zi_product_demo.
  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD read.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD lock.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD extendplant.

    DATA : lt_product TYPE TABLE FOR READ RESULT zi_product_demo.

    DATA(lt_keys) = keys.
    LOOP AT keys  ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_keys>).

      DATA(lv_plant) = <lfs_keys>-%param-plant.
      DATA(lv_product) = <lfs_keys>-%key-Product.

    ENDLOOP.

*-- Modify the entity with plant
    MODIFY ENTITY I_ProductTP_2
        CREATE BY \_ProductPlant AUTO FILL CID WITH VALUE #( ( Product = lv_product
            %target = VALUE #( ( Product = lv_product
                                   Plant = lv_plant  ) ) ) )
    MAPPED DATA(ls_mapped)
    REPORTED DATA(ls_reported)
    FAILED DATA(ls_failed).

*-- Read the changed data.
    READ ENTITIES OF zi_product_demo IN LOCAL MODE
    ENTITY ZI_product_demo
    ALL FIELDS WITH
    CORRESPONDING #( lt_keys )
     RESULT DATA(lt_result).

    result = VALUE #( FOR ls IN lt_result ( %tky = ls-%tky
                                            %param = ls ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Re: New Visual Identity - Corbu Theme for ESS/MSS
A Handy Custom Report to Scan SAP CDS Views for Usage of Search Strings
entry.content:
Introduction

Have you ever wished for an easier way to scan all your SAP CDS Views for particular strings, just as easily as you can do with ABAP reports via program RS_ABAP_SOURCE_SCAN? If you work with CDS extensively‚Äîespecially with custom developments‚Äîthe need often arises to mass-search your repository for usage of table names, fields, function modules, or any arbitrary string within CDS source code.

Inspired by this requirement, I built a custom utility report (ZSCAN_CDS_VIEWS) that you can run directly from SE38. It allows you to enter a list of search strings and instantly scans all CDS Views whose names begin with "Z," showing exactly which CDS View and which code line contains your search string. This can be particularly helpful during refactoring, code reviews, or cleanup tasks.

You can also modify the selection criteria and adjust other logic as needed to suit your specific requirements.

You might already be aware that ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in Eclipse offer an "ABAP Source Search" feature, which is also capable of searching through CDS View sources. This tool can be handy for performing code searches directly within your development environment.

However, in my experience, the source search in ADT is not as user-friendly for some scenarios:

  • The UI can be a bit overwhelming, especially if you just want a quick list of where a string is used across dozens or hundreds of custom CDS Views.
  • It's not easy to search for multiple strings at once.

Prerequisites

To make this report work, you‚Äôll need the Function Module /ABEX/SEFW_MOD_CVA_HANA available and active in your SAP system. This FM is used to read HANA DDL sources for CDS views. Internally, it calls the method /abex/cl_main_hana~read_src to fetch the source code lines.

How the Solution Works

The approach is simple but very effective:

  1. Fetch All Custom CDS Views: The program selects all entries in table DDDDLSRC where DDLNAME starts with 'Z'.
  2. Read Source for Each View: For each CDS View found, it uses /ABEX/SEFW_MOD_CVA_HANA to fetch the source code as a table of strings.
  3. Scan for Your Search Strings: For every entry in your search list, it scans the code using the ABAP FIND ALL OCCURRENCES OF ... IN TABLE statement, efficiently identifying every match.
  4. Show the Results in ALV: The results are shown in a flexible ALV grid, making it easy to filter, sort, or export as needed.

ABAP Code

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZSCAN_CDS_VIEWS
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT zscan_cds_views.

DATA: gv_sstring TYPE text255.
SELECT-OPTIONS sstring FOR gv_sstring NO INTERVALS.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_final,
         objectname   TYPE objectname,
         searchstring TYPE text255,
         line         TYPE text255,
       END OF ty_final.

DATA: gt_final    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_final,
      gt_src      TYPE /abex/string_tt,
      gt_ddddlsrc TYPE TABLE OF ddddlsrc,
      gv_name     TYPE objectname.

FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_ddddlsrc> TYPE ddddlsrc,
               <fs_src>      TYPE LINE OF /abex/string_tt,
               <fs_result>   TYPE match_result.

" --- Read all CDS sources into internal table, where DDL name starts with Z
SELECT * FROM ddddlsrc
  INTO TABLE @gt_ddddlsrc
  WHERE ddlname LIKE 'Z%'.

LOOP AT gt_ddddlsrc ASSIGNING <fs_ddddlsrc>.

  gv_name = to_upper( <fs_ddddlsrc>-ddlname ).

  " --- Call function to get the CDS source code
  CALL FUNCTION '/ABEX/SEFW_MOD_CVA_HANA'
    EXPORTING
      lv_ddlname        = gv_name
      iv_get_auth_check = abap_false
    IMPORTING
      et_src=gt_src
    EXCEPTIONS
      no_authority      = 1
      OTHERS            = 2.

  " --- Convert gt_src to a flat table for FIND
  DATA(gt_source) = VALUE abaptxt255_tab( FOR src IN gt_src ( line = src ) ).

  LOOP AT sstring INTO DATA(ls_sstring) ##into_ok.
    FIND ALL OCCURRENCES OF ls_sstring-low IN TABLE gt_source
      IN CHARACTER MODE
      IGNORING CASE
      RESULTS DATA(lt_results).

    IF lt_results IS NOT INITIAL.
      LOOP AT lt_results ASSIGNING <fs_result>.
        TRY.
            APPEND VALUE ty_final(
              objectname   = gv_name
              searchstring = ls_sstring-low
              line         = gt_src[ <fs_result>-line ]
            ) TO gt_final.
          CATCH cx_sy_itab_line_not_found.
        ENDTRY.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.

ENDLOOP.

" --- Display with SALV
DATA: lo_alv TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table.
cl_salv_table=>factory(
  IMPORTING
    r_salv_table = lo_alv
  CHANGING
    t_table      = gt_final ).

DATA(lo_columns) = lo_alv->get_columns( ).
lo_columns->get_column( 'SEARCHSTRING' )->set_long_text( 'Search String' ).
lo_columns->get_column( 'LINE' )->set_long_text( 'Code Line' ).
lo_columns->set_optimize( abap_true ).
lo_alv->display( ).

 

A Few Implementation Notes

  • Performance: For large systems with lots of CDS Views, this report might take a little time to run. You can adjust the initial selection in the SELECT statement (e.g., limit to a specific namespace) if needed.
  • Enhancements: You could easily enhance this to include other filters, save the results, or adjust the output fields. The core scan logic is highly flexible.
  • Authorization: Keep in mind that fucntion module /ABEX/SEFW_MOD_CVA_HANA must be available and properly authorized for your user.

Conclusion

This utility has saved me a lot of manual searching and helped me understand the impact of changes and references within CDS Views much quicker. I hope you find it just as useful. If you try this out and find it helpful, or if you enhance it or spot improvement opportunities, please do share your experiences in the comments.

Happy coding.

Execution 

I want to check how many CDS views use TVARVC variables. I provided the variable names in the search string as input and executed the report.

Output

entry.title: How To Consume External APIs in S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (PCE) 2023 via RAP Framework
entry.content:
Scenario:
Suppose we need to expose images related to a "PickTicket" from an external system, making them available in SAP via a custom OData service.

Steps Overview

1. Create a Custom Entity CDS View
2. Create Service Definition
3. Create Service Binding
4. Implement ABAP Class to Consume the External API
5. Test the OData Service

1. Create a Custom Entity (CDS View)

Start by defining a **custom entity** to represent the data structure for the API response:

@EndUserText.label: 'Custom Entity for Image Data'
@ObjectModel: {
query: {
implementedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_IMAGESET'
}
}
define root custom entity ZCE_IMAGESET
{
key pickticketid : abap.char(20);
key urlshortlivedthumbnail : abap.char(255);
trigger_ : abap.char(20);
source : abap.char(40);
imageid : abap.char(20);
urlthumbnail : abap.char(255);
urlshortlived : abap.char(255);
}

This entity acts as a **virtual view**‚Äîdata retrieval is handled by an ABAP class (see `implementedBy` above).

2. Create a Service Definition

Expose the custom entity in your service definition:

@EndUserText.label: 'zsd_imageset'
define service Zsd_imageset {
expose ZCE_IMAGESET;
}

3. Create a Service Binding

Next, create a **service binding**‚Äîfor example, `ZSB_IMAGESET` for OData V4‚Äîwhich generates the OData endpoint for your application. *Use the standard RAP tools in Eclipse or ADT to create this binding from the CDS service definition.*

4. Implement the ABAP Class to Handle API Call

Define the ABAP class (`zcl_imageset`) to fetch and provide data from the external API.
Use the **RAP Query Provider Interface** (`if_rap_query_provider`) for custom data provisioning:

Class Definition

CLASS zcl_imageset DEFINITION
PUBLIC
FINAL
CREATE PUBLIC .

PUBLIC SECTION.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_imageset,
trigger TYPE char20,
pickticketid TYPE char20,
source TYPE char40,
imageid TYPE char20,
urlthumbnail TYPE char255,
urlshortlived TYPE char255,
urlshortlivedthumbnail TYPE char255,
END OF ty_imageset.

TYPES: tt_imageset TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_imageset WITH EMPTY KEY.

INTERFACES if_rap_query_provider.
PROTECTED SECTION.
PRIVATE SECTION.
ENDCLASS.

Class Implementation

CLASS ZCL_IMAGESET IMPLEMENTATION.

METHOD if_rap_query_provider~select.

DATA lt_images TYPE tt_imageset.
DATA lv_pickticketid TYPE string.

" Get filter (PickTicketId)

DATA(lo_filter) = io_request->get_filter( )->get_as_sql_string( ).
DATA(lv_offset) = io_request->get_paging( )->get_offset( ).
DATA(lv_page_size) = io_request->get_paging( )->get_page_size( ).
DATA(lv_max_rows) = COND #( WHEN lv_page_size = if_rap_query_paging=>page_size_unlimited THEN 0
ELSE lv_page_size ).
DATA(lt_sort_table) = VALUE string_table( FOR ls_sort_element IN io_request->get_sort_elements( )
( ls_sort_element-element_name && COND #( WHEN ls_sort_element-descending = abap_true THEN ` descending` ELSE ` ascending` ) ) ).
CONCATENATE 'PICKTICKETID ' 'SOURCE'
INTO DATA(lv_default_sort) SEPARATED BY ',' .
DATA(lv_sort_string) = COND #( WHEN lt_sort_table IS INITIAL THEN lv_default_sort
ELSE concat_lines_of( table = lt_sort_table sep = ',' ) ).


IF io_request IS BOUND.
DATA(lt_expressions) = io_request->get_filter( )->get_as_ranges( ).


LOOP AT lt_expressions INTO DATA(ls_expr).
IF ls_expr-name = 'PICKTICKETID'.
LOOP AT ls_expr-range INTO DATA(ls_range).
IF ls_range-option = 'EQ'.
lv_pickticketid = ls_range-low.
EXIT.
ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.
EXIT.
ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.

ENDIF.

" Build target URL for the external request
DATA(lv_url) = |https://<external domain url>/pickTickets/{ lv_pickticketid }/images|.

" Create HTTP client and set headers
DATA lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.
cl_http_client=>create_by_url(
EXPORTING url = lv_url
IMPORTING client = lo_http_client
).
lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'client_id' value = '<your_client_id>' ).
lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'client_secret' value = '<your_client_secret>' ).
lo_http_client->send( ).
lo_http_client->receive( ).
DATA(lv_response) = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
lo_http_client->close( ).

" Parse JSON response to ABAP table
DATA(lo_json) = NEW /ui2/cl_json( ).
lo_json->deserialize(
EXPORTING json = lv_response
CHANGING data = lt_images
).

" Return the data
io_response->set_total_number_of_records( lines( lt_images ) ).
io_response->set_data( lt_images ).

ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

*Replace* `<external domain url>`, `<your_client_id>`, and `<your_client_secret>` *with real values.*

5. Publish and Test Your OData Service

  • Use `/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE` or the service binding UI in Eclipse/ADT to publish your OData service.
  • Test the endpoint with a filter on `PickTicketId`:
    Example: /sap/opu/odata/sap/ZSB_IMAGESET/ZCE_IMAGESET?$filter= pickticketid eq '123456'

Key Takeaways

  • Custom Entities in RAP allow you to virtualize data from external sources as standard OData.
  • You can leverage the **HTTP client functionalities** in ABAP to fetch data from any REST API.
  • RAP and ABAP Cloud stack are open for API-driven architectures.
  • Make sure to treat secrets and API credentials securely‚Äîavoid hardcoding in productive code.

Conclusion

You now have a **custom OData service** in SAP S/4HANA PCE, powered by the RAP framework, which brings in dynamic data from an **external API**. You can enhance, secure, and extend this pattern for many integration use cases‚Äîbe it analytics dashboards, mobile apps, or UI5/Fiori apps!

Let me know your feedback, or reach out for specific questions.

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud Integration/CPI: How to Return Custom Error Messages to Sender - available options
entry.content:
Good points on how to return custom error response back to caller using exception block + normal end step + good use of custom status, @MateuszPiotrowski .

I would use similar approach too if need return some error response back. Additionally, capture the response body that failed (e.g. http/soap response), http code when failed, along with msg id, return them all together back to caller, as xml or json.

generally, I will re-use body + error msg + http code that happen at the point failure, so that cover majority cases, stay consistent. And only set specific error message or custom message, if know for sure is caused by particular error, since the exception block is "catch all", mean any kind of error also possible could trigger it, so, don't want risk unexpected data/mapping error, wrongly set as Auth/401 error in response.

alternatively, uncheck at http adapter 'throw exception at failure', then manually check http response code, if is not 200-series, then manually build some response message back to caller.

entry.title: Asset Reporting in Test System
entry.content:
Hi there, 

I have a request from a business user to make a change to a standard Asset Report (S_ALR_87011964).

However, when I go to run this report in our test system, I get the following message. 

"Fiscal year change not yet made for company code 1140. Message no. AB059"

Then when I go to transaction AJRW, I get the following message "NOTE: The fiscal year change is only a technical step, needed in order to carry forward all assets into the new fiscal year. The fiscal year change has nothing to do with the YEAR-END CLOSING for bookkeeping. In order to close the annual values in Asset Accounting for a given fiscal year, you are required to carry out YEAR-END CLOSING in Asset Accounting BEFORE the year-end closing for
the general ledger. "

So my question is - is there any short-cut/work-around that can be done to mimic/bypass year end closing in our Test environments? This has not been processed in any of our test system since go-live (10 years ago) so would involve a lot of work now just so that we can test an Asset report.

Thanks,

Avril

entry.title: The Curious Case of SAP Community Moderation: A Study in Arbitrary Excellence
entry.content:
The Curious Case of SAP Community Moderation: A Study in Arbitrary Excellence

There's something almost admirable about a system so perfectly calibrated to frustrate its most dedicated contributors. SAP Community's moderation team has achieved what few organisations dare to attempt: the complete democratisation of confusion.

The Algorithm Knows Best

Picture this: you've spent hours crafting a technical blog post. You hit publish. Within moments, the machine learning system ‚Äî trained, presumably, by a committee of caffeinated squirrels ‚Äî determines your carefully researched content is indistinguishable from Nigerian prince correspondence. Welcome to spam jail.

But fear not! The moderators check the filter "regularly." Your content will resurface within 24 business hours. Or minutes. Or perhaps never. The timeline, much like the moderation logic itself, remains charmingly mysterious.

A Tale of Two Blogs

Here's where it gets genuinely fascinating.

A blog post about shell command execution in SAP CPI  ‚Äî

https://community.sap.com/t5/integration-blog-posts/getting-unconventional-with-groovy-part-1-executing-shell-commands-reading/ba-p/14294407#M2049

 

one that, by the author's own assessment, "doesn't reveal 10% of what already existing articles reveal" ‚Äî gets nuked from orbit.

Meanwhile, this gem about terminal access to CPI runtime 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/terminal-access-to-cpi-runtime-execution-of-shell-commands-on-cpi-runtime/ba-p/13460198

has been sunbathing peacefully on the platform for five years. Five. Years.

And what about this post detailing PGP secret keyring handling 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/pgp-secret-keyring-in-cpi-the-lost-passphrase-recovery/ba-p/13491284

? If we're genuinely concerned about security implications, one might think exposing cryptographic key management deserves more scrutiny than reading a file via shell script. But no. That one's fine. Perfectly fine.

The logic? There isn't any. Or if there is, it's locked in a vault somewhere, guarded by the same people who decided "Moderator 972001" was an appropriately human identifier.

The Silence Says Everything

When these inconsistencies are raised ‚Äî politely at first, then with understandable frustration ‚Äî the response is instructive in its absence.

No explanation. No acknowledgment. No "we'll look into it."

Just the digital equivalent of being shown the door while someone pretends to be very busy with paperwork.

As one contributor put it: "Is there no accountability left?"

The answer, delivered through elegant silence, appears to be: correct.

Transparency? Never Heard of Her

The moderation team operates with the transparency of a brick wall painted black and placed in a basement with no stairs. Decisions materialise from the void. Appeals dissolve into it.

"Moderator 972001" ‚Äî a designation that radiates all the warmth and humanity of a tax audit ‚Äî can apparently remove two blogs in three days from the same contributor without so much as a form letter explaining why.

One might ask: is this moderator a real person? A bot? A random number generator with delete privileges?

The community may never know. And that, apparently, is by design.

The God Complex, Quantified

There's a specific institutional pathology at play here. It's the quiet arrogance of systems that punish engagement, reward silence, and treat questions about their own behaviour as an inconvenience.

When contributors ask "Are the moderators operating in good faith?" ‚Äî a reasonable question given the evidence ‚Äî the absence of any response tells you everything.

In Conclusion

The SAP Community moderation team has built something remarkable: a platform where the most knowledgeable contributors are rewarded with suspicion, inconsistency, and bureaucratic indifference.

One needn't resort to profanity to describe them. Their work speaks eloquently enough.

entry.title: SAP Build apps (low-code) source code management
entry.content:
Hi there,

we developed our first SAP Build apps (low-code). I wonder if it is possible to export the projects into a git repository. I know the projects can be downloaded manually, but this has many drawbacks imo. Instead, I would prefer to store the project in a git repo for example.

Why? I'm biased with SAP Build Apps (low-code). It often did not work correctly and we had to unsubscripe and subscribe to it back again. Often it works but at some point we discover lots of different issues, like non-availability of fundamental services. By deleting the subscription and subscribe agian, it is fixed until next time.

Once you unsubscribe, all projects will be lost. This will not be accepted by our users, which spends lots of time to build the apps by themself. 

Is there any option to store the projects in a git? Downloading them manually is not an option at all imo. This can be a time-consuming and error-prone task.

entry.title: DRC Colombia ‚Äì Number Range Assignment for Support Documents (Non-Obligated Vendors) in S/4HANA Clou
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are currently implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 with Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) for Colombia, and we would like to request clarification regarding the number range assignment for Support Documents (Documento Soporte) issued to vendors not obligated to invoice electronically, as required by DIAN.

Context

  • DIAN has issued one Software ID for the company.

  • Using the standard app ‚ÄúGet Tax Authority Invoice Number Ranges (Colombia)‚Äù, the system successfully retrieves and assigns electronic invoice number ranges.

  • However, when executing the app again, only electronic invoice ranges are returned, and no number ranges related to Support Documents are retrieved.

Key Question

For Documento Soporte, which requires a separate DIAN-authorized number range and resolution, we would like to understand the standard SAP approach in S/4HANA Cloud Public:

  1. Is there any other standard app to retrieve Support Document number ranges from DIAN?

  2. Should Support Document ranges always be maintained manually in S/4HANA Cloud?

  3. If manual maintenance is expected:

    • Which standard configuration apps / SSCUIs should be used to register the DIAN resolution and number range?

    • How should this range be correctly assigned to the Support Document eDocument type in DRC?

  4. Is it expected behavior that ‚ÄúGet Tax Authority Invoice Number Ranges (Colombia)‚Äù only retrieves electronic invoice ranges and excludes Support Documents?

Goal

We want to ensure:

  • Full compliance with DIAN regulations

  • Usage of standard functionality only (no custom developments)

  • Correct and auditable numbering for Support Documents in DRC Colombia

Any guidance, official SAP notes, or best-practice confirmation would be highly appreciated.

Thank you very much for your support.

Best regards,

Juan Sebastian Valencia

entry.title: From Processes to Intelligence: How Manufacturing Is Entering the Cognitive Era
entry.content:
Manufacturing is entering a phase where efficiency alone is no longer enough. Volatility in supply chains, rising material costs, sustainability mandates, electrification, and shrinking margins are forcing manufacturers, especially automotive OEMs and Tier-1 suppliers, to understand their processes at a level never required before.

This is where Process Intelligence (PI) and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) together are becoming transformational.

The Manufacturing Reality: Complexity at Scale

Modern manufacturing enterprises operate across:

  • Hundreds of plants and suppliers

  • Thousands of SKUs and variants

  • Multiple ERP, MES, PLM, WMS, and quality systems

  • Highly regulated sustainability and compliance frameworks

Yet most decisions are still made using static reports, lagging KPIs, and tribal knowledge.

The result?

  • Hidden process inefficiencies

  • Excess inventory and rework

  • Poor root-cause visibility

  • Slow decision cycles

  • Underutilized data assets

What Is Process Intelligence in Manufacturing?

Process Intelligence combines:

  • Process Mining ‚Äì discovering real process flows from system logs

  • Process Performance Analytics ‚Äì measuring deviations, bottlenecks, and value leakage

  • Conformance & Root-Cause Analysis ‚Äì identifying why processes fail

In manufacturing, this means moving from how we think work happens to how work actually happens.

Examples:

  • Why does production planning frequently override MRP suggestions?

  • Where exactly are lead times increasing‚Äîsupplier, plant, or logistics?

  • Why do quality defects spike after certain engineering changes?

  • Which plants truly follow standard work, and which don‚Äôt?

Unlike traditional BI, Process Intelligence is process-centric, event-driven, and causal.

Why Automotive Manufacturing Needs Process Intelligence More Than Ever

Automotive is arguably the most process-intensive manufacturing sector in the world.

Automotive-specific challenges:

  • High product complexity and variant explosion

  • Long, multi-tier supplier networks

  • Just-in-time and just-in-sequence dependencies

  • Warranty, recall, and compliance risks

  • Transition to EVs, software-defined vehicles, and circular economy models

Where Process Intelligence Delivers Immediate Value:

  1. Order-to-Production Alignment
    Identify where sales volatility or last-minute changes disrupt production schedules.

  2. Production & Quality Loops
    Trace defects back to machine, shift, supplier, or engineering change.

  3. Inventory & Working Capital
    Reveal where buffers hide inefficiencies rather than mitigate risk.

  4. After-Sales & Warranty Analytics
    Connect manufacturing deviations to field failures and recalls.

  5. EV & Battery Lifecycle Processes
    Track traceability, compliance, remanufacturing, and recycling readiness.

The Missing Layer: Why Process Intelligence Alone Is Not Enough

Even with world-class Process Intelligence, manufacturers face a critical gap:

Insights exist, but they are not easily consumable by decision-makers.

Challenges:

  • Insights remain trapped in dashboards

  • Root causes require expert interpretation

  • Business users struggle to ask the ‚Äúright‚Äù questions

  • Knowledge is fragmented across SOPs, engineering docs, audit reports, and emails

This is where RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) changes the game.

RAG Explained in a Manufacturing Context

RAG combines Generative AI with enterprise knowledge retrieval, ensuring that AI responses are:

  • Grounded in trusted enterprise data

  • Contextual to process, plant, product, and role

  • Explainable and auditable

Instead of hallucinating answers, RAG retrieves facts from:

  • ERP & MES logs

  • Process Intelligence insights

  • SOPs, quality manuals, work instructions

  • Engineering change documents

  • Audit, ESG, and compliance records

Process Intelligence + RAG: A New Operating Model

When Process Intelligence feeds RAG, manufacturers move from analytics to intelligence-driven action.

Example Automotive Questions RAG Can Answer:

  • ‚ÄúWhy are battery pack rejects higher in Plant B this month?‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúWhich EV components are better suited for remanufacturing vs recycling?‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúWhat process deviations most impact warranty claims?‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúWhich suppliers consistently trigger line stoppages?‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúHow will a design change impact production lead time and scrap?‚Äù

The answers are:

  • Data-backed

  • Process-aware

  • Context-specific

  • Explainable

Strategic Impact Across the Automotive Value Chain

 Area  Impact of PI + RAG
Manufacturing OperationsFaster root-cause resolution, higher OEE
Supply ChainPredictive disruption insights
Quality & ComplianceReduced recalls, better audit readiness
SustainabilityMeasurable circularity and CO‚ÇÇ reduction
LeadershipDecision-making at the speed of conversation

Alignment with SAP-Centric Landscapes

In SAP-driven enterprises, Process Intelligence and RAG naturally extend platforms such as:

  • S/4HANA

  • SAP Signavio

  • SAP Digital Manufacturing

  • SAP EWM, QM, PP, PM

They act as the intelligence layer on top of transactional excellence, converting data exhaust into strategic advantage‚Äîwithout disrupting core systems.

The Future: From Dashboards to Cognitive Manufacturing

The future manufacturing enterprise will not ask:

‚ÄúWhat does the dashboard say?‚Äù

Instead, it will ask:

‚ÄúWhat should we do next‚Äîand why?‚Äù

Process Intelligence provides the ‚Äútruth.‚Äù
RAG provides the ‚Äúunderstanding.‚Äù
Together, they enable cognitive, resilient, and sustainable manufacturing.

For the automotive sector‚Äînavigating electrification, circular economy mandates, and margin pressure‚Äîthis combination is no longer optional. It is foundational.

Final Thought

Manufacturing competitiveness will increasingly be defined not by automation alone, but by how intelligently enterprises understand, question, and continuously improve their processes.

Process Intelligence + RAG is not just a technology stack‚Äîit is a new way of running manufacturing.
